_header: Jesu Lord our heaven king / Grant us all…
_description: Syr Egyllamore of Artas — generally in 12-line stanzas (aabccbddbeeb)

BodDou261.First Lines:
Than hys doughter so freeSo dyd she that gentyll
                    knyght…
BodDou261.Last Lines:
…Deare Jesus brynge vs to thy blysseThat lasteth without
                    ende
BodDou261.Note: Fragment; transcript of an early print.
BodDou261.Attributed Title: IHS 1564 Here endeth Syr Eglamoure of Arttys (f. 48)

CULFf238.First Lines:
Ihesu lorde oure heuyn kyngeGraunt vs all thy dere
                    blessynge…
CULFf238.Last Lines:
…Ihesu brynge vs to that blysThat lastyth with owten ende
                    Amen
CULFf238.Attributed Title:
Here…begynnethe Syr Egyllamoure of artas (f. 70vb); Here
                    endyth Sir Egtyllamowre of artas… (colophon, f. 79rb)
CULFf238.Facsimiles:
McSparran,  Frances,  and  Pamela R. Robinson.  
             “Introduction.” 
             Cambridge University Library MS Ff.2.38.
         London: Scolar Press, 1979.
CULFf238.Editions:
Halliwell-Phillipps,  James Orchard,
                        ed.  
             The Thornton Romances: The Early English Metrical Romances of Perceval,
                Isumbras, Eglamour, and Degrevant.
Camden Society
         o.s. 30 (1844); repr. F.S. Ellis, Kelmscott Press, 1897: 121-76.

BlCottCalAII.First Lines:
Ihesu crist of heuen kyngGraunt vs all good
                    endyng…
BlCottCalAII.Last Lines:
…Ihesu brynge vs to hys blysThat neuyr schall haue
                    ende
BlCottCalAII.Attributed Title:
Eglamour of Artas (by scribe, upper margin f. 5v); Eglamour (RT
                    on verso leaves thereafter); Explicit Eglamour of Artas (by scribe, f.
                        13rb); Another old english poeme intitled Eglamore of Artois (f.
                    1, sixteenth-century list of contents)
BlCottCalAII.Editions:
Hudson,  Harriet,
                        ed.  
             Four Middle English
                    Romances: Sir Isumbras, Octavian, Sir Eglamour of Artois, Sir
                Tryamour.
         Kalamazoo, MI: Western Michigan University for TEAMS, 1996. 2nd ed.
            2006.

BLEge2862.First Lines: Ihu þat is heuyn kingSend vs al good endyng…
BLEge2862.Last Lines: …But ȝe amende him of his fareHe leuyþ not þis þre nyȝte…
BLEge2862.Note: Fragment: lines 1-160; one leaf only survives. Most of second column on f. 148v illegible so lines are from bottom of first column, 40 more lines in column b.
BLEge2862.Editions:
Kölbing,  Eugen. 
             “Amis and Amiloun zugleich mit der altfranzösischen Quelle, nebst
                einter Bilage Amicus ok Amilius Rimur.” 
             Altenglische Bibliothek
         2 Heilbronn: Henninger, 1884: 193.

BLAdd27879.Editions:
Hales,  John Wesley,  and  Frederick James Furnivall, eds.  
             Bishop Percy’s Folio Manuscript: Ballads and Romances.
         3 vols. London: Trübner, 1867-68: 2.341-89.

Lincoln91.First Lines:
Ihesu þat es heuens kyngGyff vs alle his
                    blyssyng…
Lincoln91.Last Lines:
In rome þis romance crouned esNow Ihesu brynge vs to his
                    blysseÞat lastis with owttyn ende AmenAmen Amen par
                        charyte Amen
Lincoln91.Note: Parts of ff. 144, 145, 146 torn away with loss of text.
Lincoln91.Facsimiles:
Brewer,  Derek Stanley,  and  A. E. B. Owen.  
             “Introduction.” 
             The Thornton Manuscript (Lincoln Cathedral MS. 91).
         London: Scolar Press, 1975.
